questions.question: Question 1: What is the most common hereditary disease associated with life-threatening bleeding?
questions.explanation:
The most common hereditary disease associated with life-threatening bleeding is hemophilia 
A. It is caused by mutations in factor VIII, an essential cofactor for factor IX in the coagulation 
cascade. Note: von Willebrand disease is the most common inherited bleeding disorder.

questions.question:
Question 2: A 12-year-old boy presents with the following finding after a trivial fall. His lab investigations 
are given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario showing hemarthrosis and elevated aPTT is suggestive of hemophilia. Specific tests for measuring levels of factor VIII and factor IX can determine whether it is 
hemophilia A or hemophilia B respectively. Clinical features of hemophilia: • Hemarthroses - joint hemorrhages, later causing progressive deformities • Recurrent bleeding • Pseudotumour syndrome - fascial hemorrhages that occur as blood-filled cysts with calcification 
and proliferation of fibroblasts, giving the appearance of the tumor It is associated with elevated aPTT and normal platelet count, bleeding time, and PT. Option A: In ITP, the platelet count is low and bleeding time is prolonged. Option B: In functional platelet disorders, like Bernard Soulier syndrome, the platelet count is 
normal and bleeding time is prolonged. Option D: In vitamin K deficiency, both PT and aPTT are prolonged. PT is relatively more 
prolonged than is the aPTT. 437 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 3: 432 
Sold by @itachibot A 7-year-old boy was found to have excessive bleeding following tooth extraction. Lab 
investigations revealed prolonged aPTT, decreased serum factor VIII levels and normal VwF 
activity. What is the mode of inheritance of this condition?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Hemophilia A (factor VIII deficiency). It is inherited as 
an X-linked recessive trait. Hence, it affects mainly males and homozygous females. Hemophilia B is also inherited as X-linked recessive trait. Hemophilia C is inherited as an autosomal-recessive trait.

questions.question: Question 4: Which of the following statements is false about hemophilia?

options.c: Hemophilia A in female may indicate unfavourable lyonization
options.d: Hemophilia A can occur without any family history

questions.explanation:
Hemophilia A and B mostly affect males, but rarely can affect females also. Hemophilia A is an X-linked recessive disorder, affecting mainly males and homozygous 
females. Rarely, excessive bleeding occurs in heterozygous females. It is due to the inactivation of 
the X chromosome bearing the normal factor VIII allele by chance in most cells 
(unfavourable lyonization). About 30% of patients have no family history and the disorder is 
caused due to new mutations. Hemophilia B is inherited as X-linked recessive trait. There is a deficiency of factor IX. Hemophilia C is an autosomal-recessive condition and hence can occur in females. There is 
a deficiency of factor XI.

questions.question: Question 6: Which of the following lab findings are seen in patients with hemophilia A?
questions.explanation:
Patients with hemophilia A have: • Prolonged partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) - intrinsic pathway abnormality • Normal prothrombin time (PT) 438 
Sold by @itachibot • Normal bleeding time • Normal platelet count

questions.question:
Question 7: A newborn baby develops severe umbilical cord bleeding soon after birth. Lab investigations 
are given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given scenario is suggestive of factor XIII deficiency. A positive urea lysis test confirms the 
diagnosis. Factor XIII is also known as clot-stabilizing factor that converts unstable fibrin clot into a stable 
clot. Its deficiency typically presents as excessive umbilical cord bleeding in the newborn. Laboratory findings in this condition are: • Normal levels of bleeding time (BT), platelet count, prothrombin time (PT), activated partial 
thromboplastin time (aPTT), and thrombin time (TT) • Positive urea lysis test - confirmatory test which demonstrates lysis of clot by hyperosmolar urea

questions.question:
Question 8: A Hemogram of a 23-year-old patient with a bleeding disorder is given below. Which of the 
following would you use to differentiate between heparin-induced thrombocytopenia and 
afibrinogenemia in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Reptilase is a thrombin agonist which is used to differentiate heparin-induced thrombocytopenia 
(HIT) and afibrinogenemia. It is resistant to the action of heparin. The differential diagnosis for normal platelet count with elevated PT, aPTT and TT are HIT 
and afibrinogenemia. After adding reptilase, if the TT is corrected, it points to HIT. 
In afibrinogenemia, since there is an absence of fibrin, there is no change in the TT.

questions.question:
Question 9: A 1-year-old child was diagnosed to have Kasabach-Merritt syndrome. What is this condition 
associated with?
questions.explanation:
439 
Sold by @itachibot Kasabach–Merritt syndrome is associated with DIC (disseminated intravascular coagulation). This 
syndrome is characterised by the following features: • Rapidly growing vascular tumour • Thrombocytopenia • Microangiopathic haemolytic anaemia • Consumptive coagulopathy An unusual form of DIC occurs in association with giant hemangiomas. In this type, stasis and 
recurrent trauma to the fragile blood vessels cause thrombi to form within the neoplasm. The image given below shows a reddish-blue lesion covering the lower part of the abdomen. It 
is a caverno-capillary haemangioma seen in Kasabach–Merritt syndrome.

questions.question: Question 10: Which of the following clotting factor deficiency will not affect clotting in vivo?
questions.explanation:
Factor XII deficiency will not affect the clotting in vivo. Unlike the clotting cascade in the lab (in vitro), the cascade in the body (in vivo) differs slightly - 
as tissue factor (TF) is the major initiator of the cascade. The TF/VIIa complex is the most 
important activator of factor IX and factor IXa/factor VIIIa complex is the most important 
activator of factor X. Factor V is involved in both the pathways as shown in the image below. The coagulation cascade in the laboratory: • Extrinsic pathway sequence (in a test tube): Tissue factor  Factor VII  Factor X. • Intrinsic pathway sequence (in a test tube): Factor XII  Factor XI  Factor IX  Factor X Laboratory methods to initiate clotting include: • Intrinsic pathway - adding phospholipids, calcium, and either a negatively charged substance 
such as glass beads 440 
Sold by @itachibot • Extrinsic pathway - a source of tissue factor

questions.question: Question 11: Which test evaluates the extrinsic pathway?
questions.explanation:
Prothrombin time (PT) evaluates the extrinsic pathway of coagulation. PT measures the clotting time of plasma in the presence of an optimal concentration of tissue 
extract (thromboplastin). This indicates the overall efficiency of the extrinsic clotting system. Causes of prolonged PT: • Administration of oral anticoagulant drugs - vitamin K antagonists • Liver disease - obstructive jaundice • Vitamin K deficiency • Disseminated intravascular coagulation • Previously undiagnosed factor VII, X, V or prothrombin deficiency or defect (rare) Activated partial thromboplastin time (APTT) measures the clotting time of plasma after the 
activation of contact factors and the addition of phospholipid and CaCl2, but without added tissue 
thromboplastin. It indicates the overall efficiency of the intrinsic pathway. Causes of prolonged APTT: • Disseminated intravascular coagulation • Liver disease • Massive transfusion with plasma-depleted red blood cells • Administration of or contamination with heparin or other anticoagulants • A circulating anticoagulant (inhibitor) • Deficiency of a coagulation factor other than factor VII 441 
Sold by @itachibot • Intake of oral anticoagulant drugs • Vitamin K deficiency

questions.question:
Question 13: At what temperature should you store the sample for antiphospholipid antibody factor 
assays?
questions.explanation: The sample for antiphospholipid antibody assay must be stored at <4°. Samples for coagulation studies should be stored always at room temperature (20 to 25 degrees).

questions.question:
Question 14: A 50-year-old male patient presents to the casualty with severe bleeding following a road 
traffic accident. He is a known cardiac disease patient on anticoagulant therapy. As an intern, 
you were asked to collect blood for coagulation studies. Which colour vacutainer will you 
pick? 435 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The most commonly used vacutainer for coagulation studies is a blue vacutainer containing 
trisodium citrate. The benefits of trisodium citrate are that the calcium ion is neutralized more rapidly in citrate. Other anticoagulants are unacceptable for coagulation studies. The labile factors (factors V 
and VIII) are unstable in oxalate (grey), whereas heparin (green) and EDTA (lavender) directly 
inhibit the coagulation process and interfere with end-point determinations. Also, activated 
partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) tests are more sensitive to the presence of heparin (green). The image given below shows colour coding of vacutainers with the anticoagulant used and their 
practical uses. 442 
Sold by @itachibot Note: Heparin is used for blood sample collection for electrolyte estimation.

questions.question: Question 15: Which of the following is the color of vacutainer containing sodium fluoride as a content?
questions.explanation: Sodium fluoride is present in the grey coloured tube. Sodium fluoride inhibits glycolysis. Hence, is used for the estimation of blood glucose and alcohol.

questions.question:
Question 16: A child was brought to the emergency department with a big lesion on his forearm. As a 
surgery resident you decide to excise the lesion in the emergency operation theatre. Which of 
the following investigations will test the entire coagulation pathway?

options.a: A young women with severe anaemia
options.c: No such time restraint and can be done anytime.
options.d: It should be completed within 6 hours of receiving from the blood bank.

questions.explanation:
Thromboelastography (TEG) tests the entire coagulation pathway. It measures coagulation 
cascade, platelet function, and fibrinolysis. It is a test that quantitatively measures the ability of whole blood to form a clot. The advantages 
are: • Global assessment of blood coagulability, including coagulation cascade, platelet function, and 
fibrinolysis • Rapid real-time bedside test with a simple methodology (point-of-care testing) • Diagnosis of coagulopathic bleeding • Guide transfusion therapy and decrease the use of blood products • 443 
Sold by @itachibot Detect dynamic changes in blood coagulation during resuscitation • Predict the clinical efficacy of therapeutic agents affecting blood coagulability 444 
Sold by @itachibot Blood Products and Transfusion Reactions
